questions.text: Nucleotides such as AMP, ADP, and ATP are the sensors of the energy status of the cell and their interconversion plays an important role in the energy homeostasis of the cell. Which of the following enzyme catalyzes the formation of AMP from two molecules of ADP?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Adenylate kinase When ATP level is reduced, AMP is formed by Adenylate kinase (ADK) in the following reaction: Adenylate kinase or myokinase is a phosphotransferase (EC no-2) It catalyzes the interconversion of adenine nucleotides (ATP, ADP, and AMP) AMP is an allosteric activator of glycolysis. Oxidative phosphorylation in mitochondria is also dependent on the availability of ADP and is maintained by the action of adenylate kinase. Some factors that modulate ADK activity and adenine nucleotide levels are Stress, exercise, hormone levels, and diet.

Adenosine kinase is an enzyme that catalyzes the transfer of gamma-phosphate from ATP to adenosine to form AMP. Its main function is to control the cellular levels of adenosine. Option: D. Adenosine deaminase Used for conversion of adenosine to Inosine by removal of the amino group in purine catabolism Important in B & T Lymphocytes Easily measured in any fluid of the body if ↑ ADA: Suggestive of TB if ↓ ADA: Both B & T are Lymphocytes affected leading to Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID?

questions.text: Kinase enzymes most often catalyze the regulatory steps of cellular oxidative metabolic pathways. Which of the following activates Kinase of glycolysis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Insulin Insulin activates all anabolic pathways/enzymes: HMP Glycogenesis FA synthesis Cholesterol synthesis TG synthesis Lipoprotein Lipase enzyme But Insulin also activates two catabolic pathway enzymes, e. Glycolysis & Link reaction. It activates: Glucokinase, PFK-1, and Pyruvate Kinase enzymes of glycolysis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option: A. ATP and other nucleotides such as ADP and AMP are allosteric regulators of enzymes of various metabolic pathways. Increased cellular ATP levels will result in a decrease in catabolic processes whereas increase AMP and ADP levels usually favor the catabolism of major fuel molecules lipids and carbohydrates. Option: B. cAMP is a secondary messenger produced from ATP by the enzyme adenylate cyclase and is responsible for the activation of protein kinases by phosphorylation. Insulin will always decrease cAMP whereas glucagon will increase its synthesis. Option: D. Glucagon activates all catabolic pathways by increasing the synthesis of cAMP resulting in the phosphorylation of protein kinase which further phosphorylates enzymes of catabolic pathways to activate them. However, as an exception, it does not activate two catabolic pathway enzymes , e. Glycolysis & Link reaction.

questions.text: A 28-year-old runner was advised to increase his carbohydrate intake after his daily training for ensuring enough muscle glycogen storage. The anabolic hormone released after such a meal will increase the activity of main muscle glycogenesis enzymes by:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Activating phosphodiesterase Insulin increases the activity of muscle glycogen synthase after the intake of carbohydrates lowering cellular cAMP levels through the activation of phosphodiesterase which converts cAMP to 5’ AMP. This results in the dephosphorylation of glycogen synthase causing its activation. (See fig. below) Simultaneously, it also decreases the activity of glycogen phosphorylase thereby decreasing glycogenolysis. Insulin does not affect the activity of adenylate cyclase. It is activated by glucagon.

questions.text: Muscle glycogen is used for the rapid release of energy for performing intense physical exercise. Glycogenolysis is activated in muscles by the activity of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Epinephrine Glycogenolysis is activated by both Glucagon and Epinephrine As glucagon receptors are not found in muscle, So, only epinephrine increases glycogenolysis in muscle. These hormones act by the action of mediator cAMP which causes phosphorylation of the enzyme of glycogen breakdown.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option: A. Glucagon Glycogenolysis is activated mainly by two hormones: glucagon & epinephrine But Glucagon receptors are not found in muscles. So, epinephrine increases glycogenolysis in muscles. Option: B. Insulin Insulin is an anabolic hormone released in a fed state and inhibits glycogenolysis. Insulin causes decreased blood glucose by its absorption into peripheral cells mediated by GLUT-4. Option: D. Growth hormone Growth hormone does not cause muscle glycogenolysis. GH promotes glycogenesis and gluconeogenesis in the liver and inhibits glycolysis So, decreases the utilization of glucose in muscles and other tissues. It also helps in the mobilization of free fatty acids from adipose tissue stores.

questions.text: Cellular metabolism is greatly affected by hormones in response to changes in external conditions. which of the following effects on metabolism is/are exerted by the hormone cortisol? ↑ Gluconeogenesis ↑ Lipogenesis ↑ Proteolysis ↑ Export of amino acid to liver ↑ Glycolysis Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 3, and 4 are correct Cortisol is a catabolic hormone-like glucagon It acts primarily on muscle, liver & adipose tissues. A variety of stressors release cortisol from the adrenal cortex. This is a relatively slow-acting hormone It will cause an increase in the following: Gluconeogenesis in the liver (by transport of amino acid substrates from peripheral tissues to the liver), Proteolysis in peripheral tissues but induction of protein synthesis in the liver (by transport of amino acid from peripheral tissues to liver).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Statement: 2. Cortisol increase lipolysis in adipose tissues by enhancing hormone-sensitive lipase and also decrease lipogenesis in adipocytes hence, causing an overall increase in blood FFA resulting in hyperlipidemia. Statement: 5. Cortisol decreases tissue uptake and metabolism of glucose (decreases glycolysis). By causing increased glucose production and decreased utilization it causes an elevated blood glucose concentration.

Low Insulin: Glucagon ratio means ⇒ Catabolic state (As low insulin means Fasting state or catabolic state) Insulin activates all anabolic enzymes with the exception that it also promotes catabolic pathways glycolysis and link reaction. Glucose-6-Phosphatase is an enzyme that is active in the fasting state / catabolic state

questions.text: Anabolic and catabolic processes in the body are generally activated in Fed and Fasting states respectively. The pathway which occurs both in Fed and Fasting state is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

TCA TCA and ETC are vital pathways that occur in both fed and fasting states. TCA and ETC do not depend on hormones. However, their activity can be either increased or decreased depending on the availability of substrates and the abundance of products respectively. For example: TCA activity is increased in the presence of oxaloacetate and acetyl CoA and decreased in the absence of NAD and FAD. Similarly, ETC activity can be decreased in the absence of oxygen.

Random:

Option: B. Glycolysis Though a small basal level of glycolysis also occurs in the fasting state, glycolysis is enhanced in the presence of insulin in the fed state to provide energy for various synthetic reactions. But the one best answer is TCA. Option: C. HMP It is an anabolic pathway that occurs in the fed state. It is the main source of NADPH (required for the synthesis of lipids) and Ribose 5-P (required for nucleotide synthesis). Option: D. Glycogenesis Glycogenesis (glycogen synthesis) occurs in the muscle and liver and is an anabolic pathway, so the activity of the enzyme of the glycogen synthesis pathway is increased by the release of insulin in the fed state.

questions.text: Phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of enzymes is one of the regulatory mechanisms for controlling their activity. Phosphorylation of which of the following enzymes will result in its activation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glycogen phosphorylase Phosphorylation is done by the hormone glucagon . Glucagon is active in fasting or under catabolic situations. So, enzymes of the catabolic pathway ( Except Glycolysis and Link reaction) will be active in the phosphorylated state Glycogen phosphorylase is an enzyme helping in the breaking down of glycogen, it is a catabolic enzyme and all catabolic enzymes which are activated by glucagon are active in the phosphorylated state

questions.text: An injection of nitroglycerin given during an angiographic procedure acts by a secondary messenger which is formed from guanine-containing nucleotide as a precursor and causes vasodilation. This secondary messenger is also involved in which of the following process:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

ANP and BNP activation Nucleotide GTP gives rise to secondary messenger cGMP by enzyme guanylate cyclase by cyclization. cGMP - It consists of guanine, ribose, and phosphate Hormones that use cGMP as a second messenger are called group IIb hormones. It has a role in the visual cycle, Vasodilatory effect by NO (nitric oxide), and activation of peptide hormones like ANP and BNP (atrial and brain natriuretic peptides). The hormones which use cAMP as a second messenger are called group IIa hormones such as: Glucagon, LH, FSH, hCG, Calcitonin, Catecholamines

questions.text: Hormone insulin promotes a number of anabolic pathways and enzymes in the cell and body. The mechanism which is NOT responsible for promoting lipogenesis by insulin is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inhibiting pyruvate dehydrogenase Insulin Increases the formation of Acetyl CoA by increasing the action of enzyme – Pyruvate Dehydrogenase e. Link reaction So, option C is wrong as insulin activates the enzyme of Link reaction i.e. Pyruvate Dehydrogenase (not inhibits).

questions.text: Compression of the nerve within the carpal tunnel produces an inability to:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

questions.text: A 19-year male presents with complaints of hypoesthesia and wasting of the thenar eminence in his right hand. The nerve most likely to be affected in this case is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Median Nerve Median nerve compression in the carpal tunnel at the wrist leads to Carpal Tunnel syndrome. This syndrome consists of motor, sensory, vasomotor, and trophic symptoms in the hand caused by compression of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel. Examination reveals wasting of thenar eminence ( ape-like hand ), and hypoesthesia to light touch on the palmar aspect of lateral 3½ digits. However, the skin over the thenar eminence is not affected as the branch of the median nerve supplying it arises in the forearm.
